Come on my boy. How dost my boy? Art cold?
I am cold myself. Where is this straw, my Fellow?
The Art of our Necessities is strange,
And can make vile things precious. Come, your Hovel;
Poor Fool, and Knave,I have one part in my heart
That is sorry yet for thee.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
He that has and a little-tyne wit,
With heigh-ho, the Wind and the Rain,
Must make content with his Fortunes fit,
Though the Rain it rains every day.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: True Boy: Come bring us to this Hovel.

sp.speaker: Fool.
Glo.
sp.l: Alack, alack Edmund, I like not this unnatural
dealing; when I desired their leave that I might pity him,
they took from me the use of mine own house, charged
me on pain of perpetual displeasure, neither to speak
of him, entreat for him, or any way sustain him.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Most savage and unnatural.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
Go to,; say you nothing. There is division between the Dukes, and a worse matter than that: I have
received a Letter this night, it is dangerous to be spoken,
I have locked the Letter in my Closet, these injuries the
King now bears, will be revenged home; there is part of
a Power already footed, we must incline to the King, I
will look him, and privily relieve him; go you and
maintain talk with the Duke, that my charity be not of
him perceived; If he ask for me, I am ill, and gone to
bed, if I die for it, (as no less is threatened me) the King
my old Master must be relieved. There is strange things
toward Edmund, pray you be careful.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: This Courtesy forbid thee, shall the Duke
Instantly know, and of that Letter too;
This seems a fair deserving, and must draw me
That which my Father looses: no less than all,
The younger rises, when the old doth fall.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Here is the place my Lord, good my Lord enter,
The tyranny of the open night is too rough
For Nature to endure.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord enter here.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Wilt break my heart?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I had rather break mine own,
Good my Lord enter.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thou thinkst it is much that this contentious storm
Invades us to the skin so: it is to thee,
But where the greater malady is fixed,
The lesser is scarce felt. Thou wouldst shun a Bear,
But if thy flight lay toward the roaring Sea,
Thou wouldst meet the Bear in the mouth, when the mind is free,
The body is delicate: the tempest in my mind,
Doth from my senses take all feeling else,
Save what beats there, Filial ingratitude,
Is it not as this mouth should tear this hand
For lifting food to it? But I will punish home;
No, I will weep no more; in such a night,
To shut me out? Pour on, I will endure:
In such a night as this? O Regan, Gonerill,
Your old kind Father, whose frank heart gave all,
O that way madness lies, let me shun that:
No more of that.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord enter here.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Prithee go in thyself, seek thine own ease,
This tempest will not give me leave to ponder
On things would hurt me more, but I will go in,
In Boy, go first. You house-less poverty,
Nay get thee in; I will pray, and then I will sleep.
Poor naked wretches, wheresoever you are
That bide the pelting of this pitiless storm,
How shall your House-less heads, and unfed sides,
Your lopped, and windowed raggedness defend you
From seasons such as these? O I have taken
Too little care of this: Take Physic, Pomp,
Expose thyself to feel what wretches feel,
That thou mayst shake the superflux to them,
And show the Heavens more just.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Fathom, and half, Fathom and half; poor Tom.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Come not in here Nuncle, here is a spirit, help
me, help me.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Give me thy hand, who is there?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
A spirit, a spirit, he says his name is poor
Tom.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: What art thou that dost grumble there in the
straw? Come forth.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Away, the foul Fiend follows me, through the
sharpe Hawthorn blow the winds. Humh, go to thy
bed and warm thee.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Didst thou give all to thy Daughters? And art
thou come to this?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Who gives anything, to poor Tom? Whom
the foul fiend hath led though Fire, and through Flame,
through Sword, and whirlpool, over Bog, and Quagmire, that hath laid Knives under his Pillow, and Halters
in his Pew, set Rats-bane by his Porridge, made him
Proud of heart, to ride on a Bay trotting Horse, over four
inched Bridges, to course his own shadow for a Traitor.
Bliss thy five Wits, Toms a-cold. O do, de, do, de, do de,
bliss thee from whirlwinds, Star-blasting, and taking, do poor Tom some charity, whom the foul Fiend
vexes. There could I have him now, and there, and there
again, and there.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Ha is his Daughters brought him to this pass?
Couldst thou save nothing? Wouldst thou give them all?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Nay, he reserved a Blanket, else we had been all
shamed.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous air
Hang fated over men's faults, light on thy Daughters.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: He hath no Daughters Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Death Traitor, nothing could have subdued Nature
To such a lowness, but his unkind Daughters.
Is it the fashion, that discarded Fathers,
Should have thus little mercy on their flesh:
Judicious punishment, it was this flesh begot
Those Pelican Daughters.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Pillicock sat on Pillicock hill, allow: allow, loo, loo.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
This cold night will turn us all to Fools,and
Madmen.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Take heed of the foul Fiend, obey thy Parents, keep thy words Justice, swear not, commit not,
with man's sworn Spouse: set not thy Sweet-heart on
proud array. Tom is a-cold.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: What hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
A Serving-man? Proud in heart, and mind; that
curled my hair, wore Gloves in my cap; served the Lust
of my Mistress heart, and did the act of darkness with
her. Swore as many Oaths, as I spake words, and broke
them in the sweet face of Heaven. One, that slept in the
contriving of Lust, and waked to do it. Wine loved I
dearly, Dice dearly;and in Woman, out-Paramoured
the Turk. False of heart, light of ear, bloody of hand;
Hog in sloth, Fox in stealth, Wolf in greediness, Dog
in madness, Lion in prey. Let not the creaking of shoes,
Nor the rustling of Silks, betray thy poor heart to woman. Keep thy foot out of Brothels, thy hand out of
Plackets, thy pen from Lenders' Books, and defy the
foul Fiend. Still through the Hawthorn blows the
cold wind: Says suum, mun, nonny, Dolphin my Boy,
Boy Sesey: let him trot by.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Thou wert better in a Grave, than to answer
with thy uncovered body, this extremity of the Skies. Is
man no more than this? Consider him well. Thou owest
the Worm no Silk; the Beast, no Hide; the Sheep, no
Wool; the Cat, no perfume. Ha? Here is three of us are
sophisticated. Thou art the thing itself; unaccommodated man, is no more but such a poor, bare, forked Animal as thou art. Off, off you Lendings: Come, unbutton here.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Prithee Nuncle be contented, it is a naughty
night to swim in. Now a little fire in a wild Field,
were like an old Lecher's heart, a small spark, all the rest
of his body, cold: Look, here comes a walking fire.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
This is the foul Flibbertigibbet; he begins at
Curfew, and walks at first Cock : He gives the Web
and the Pin, squints the eye, and makes the Harelip;
Mildews the white Wheat, and hurts the poor Creature of earth.
Swithun footed thrice the old,
He met the Night-Mare, and her nine-fold;
Bid her alight, and her troth-plight,
And aroint thee Witch, aroint thee.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: How fares your Grace?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Who is there? What is it you seek?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What are you there? Your Names?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Poor Tom, that eats the swimming Frog, the
Toad, the Tod-pole, the wall-Newt, and the water: that
in the fury of his heart, when the foul Fiend rages, eats
Cow-dung for Salads; swallows the old Rat, and the
ditch-Dog; drinks the green Mantle of the standing
Poole: who is whipped from Tithing to Tithing, and
stocked, punished, and imprisoned: who hath three Suites
to his back, six shirts to his body:
Horse to ride, and weapon to wear:
But Mice, and Rats, and such small Dear,
Have been Toms food, for seven long year:
Beware my Follower. Peace Smulkin, peace thou Fiend.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What, hath your Grace no better company?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: The Prince of Darkness is a Gentleman. Modo
he is called, and Mahu.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Our flesh and blood, my Lord, is grown so
vile, that it doth hate what gets it.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Poor Tom is a-cold.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Go in with me; my duty cannot suffer
To obey in all your daughters' hard commands:
Though their Injunction be to bar my doors,
And let this Tyrannous night take hold upon you,
Yet have I ventured to come seek you out,
And bring you where both fire, and food is ready.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: First let me talk with this Philosopher,
What is the cause of Thunder?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord take his offer,
Go into the house.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will talk a word with this same learned Theban:
What is your study?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: How to prevent the Fiend, and to kill Vermin.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Let me ask you one word in private.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Importune him once more to go my Lord,
His wits begin to unsettle.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Canst thou blame him?
His Daughters seek his death: Ah, that good Kent,
He said it would be thus: poor banished man:
Thou sayst the King grows mad, I will tell thee Friend
I am almost mad myself. I had a Son,
Now outlawed from my blood: he sought my life
But lately: very late: I loved him (Friend)
No Father his Son dearer: true to tell thee
The grief hath crazed my wits. What a night is this?
I do beseech your grace.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O cry you mercy, Sir:
Noble Philosopher, your company.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Tom is a-cold.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: In fellow there, into the Hovel; keep thee warm.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come, let us in all.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: This way, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: With him;
I will keep still with my Philosopher.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Good my Lord, sooth him:
Let him take the Fellow.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Take him you on.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Sirrah, come on: go along with us.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Come, good Athenian.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No words, no words, hush.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Child Rowland to the dark Tower came,
His word was still, fie, foh, and fum,
I smell the blood of a British man.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p: I will have my revenge, ere I depart his house.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
How my Lord, I may be censured, that Nature
thus gives way to Loyalty, something fears me to
think of.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
I now perceive, it was not altogether your
Brother's evil disposition made him seek his death: but
a provoking merit set a-work by a reprovable badness
in himself.

sp.speaker: Edm.
Corn.
sp.p: Go with me to the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
If the matter of this Paper be certain, you have
mighty business in hand.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
True or false, it hath made thee Earl of Gloucester: seek out where thy Father is, that he may be
ready for our apprehension.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.p:
If I find him comforting the King, it will stuff
his suspicion more fully. I will persevere in my course of
Loyalty, though the conflict be sore between that, and
my blood.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
I will lay trust upon thee: and thou shalt find
a dear Father in my love.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.p:
Here is better than the open air, take it thankfully: I will piece out the comfort with what addition I
can: I will not be long from you.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.p:
All the power of his wits, have given way to his
impatience: the Gods reward your kindness.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Fraterretto calls me, and tells me Nero is an Angler in the Lake of Darkness: pray Innocent, and beware
the foul Fiend.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
Prithee Nuncle tell me, whether a madman be
a Gentleman, or a Yeoman.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: A King, a King.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p:
No, he is a Yeoman, that ha is a Gentleman to
his Son: for he is a mad Yeoman that sees his Son a
Gentleman before him.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: To have a thousand with red burning spits
Come hissing in upon them.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p: Bless thy five wits.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: O pity: Sir, where is the patience now
That you so oft have boasted to retain?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: My tears begin to take his part so much,
They mar my counterfeiting.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: The little dogs, and all;
Trey, Blanch, and Sweet-heart: see, they bark at me.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Tom, will throw his head at them: Avaunt you
Curs, be thy mouth or black or white:
Tooth that poisons if it bite:
Mastiff, Grey-hound, Mongrel, Grim,
Hound or Spaniel, Brach, or Hym:
Or Bobtail tight, or Troudle tail,
Tom will make him weep and wail,
For with throwing thus my head;
Dogs leapt the hatch, and all are fled.
Do, de, de, de: sese: Come, march to Wakes and Fairs,
And Market Towns: poor Tom thy horn is dry,

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Then let them Anatomise Regan: See what
breeds about her heart. Is there any cause in Nature that
make these hard-hearts. You sir, I entertain for one of
my hundred; only, I do not like the fashion of your garments. You will say they are Persian; but let them be
changed.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Now good my Lord, lie here, and rest awhile.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Make no noise, make no noise, draw the Curtains: so, so, we will go to Supper in the morning.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And I will go to bed at noon.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Come hither Friend:
Where is the King my Master?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Here Sir, but trouble him not, his wits are gone.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Good friend, I prithee take him in thy arms;
I have ore-heard a plot of death upon him:
There is a Litter ready, lay him in it,
And drive toward Douer friend, where thou shalt meet
Both welcome, and protection. Take up thy Master,
If thou shouldest dally half an hour, his life
With thine, and all that offer to defend him,
Stand in assured loss. Take up, take up,
And follow me, that will to some provision
Give thee quick conduct. Come, come, away.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Post speedily to my Lord your husband, show
him this Letter, the Army of France is landed: seek out
the Traitor Glouster.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Hang him instantly.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Pluck out his eyes.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.p:
Leave him to my displeasure. Edmond, keep
you our Sister company: the revenges we are bound to
take upon your Traitorous Father, are not fit for your
beholding. Advise the Duke where you are going, to a
most festinate preparation: we are bound to the like. Our
Posts shall be swift, and intelligent betwixt us. Farewell dear Sister, farewell my Lord of Glouster.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: How now? Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: My Lord of Glouster hath conveyed him hence
Some five or six and thirty of his Knights
Hot Questrists after him, met him at gate,
Who, with some other of the Lords, dependants,
Are gone with him toward Douer; where they boast
To have well armed Friends.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Get horses for your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Lord, and Sister.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Edmund farewell: go seek the Traitor Gloster,
Pinion him like a Thief, bring him before us:
Though well we may not pass upon his life
Without the form of Justice: yet our power
Shall do a courtesy to our wrath, which men
May blame, but not control.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Who is there? the Traitor?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Ingrateful Fox, it is he.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Bind fast his corky arms.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What means your Graces?
Good my Friends consider you are my Guests:
Do me no foul play, Friends.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Bind him I say.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Hard, hard: O filthy Traitor.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Unmerciful Lady, as you are, I am none.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: To this Chair bind him,
Villain, thou shalt find.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: By the kind Gods, it is most ignobly done
To pluck me by the Beard.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: So white, and such a Traitor?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Naughty Lady,
These hairs which thou dost ravish from my chin
Will quicken and accuse thee. I am your Host,
With Robbers hands, my hospitable favours
You should not ruffle thus. What will you do?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Come Sir.
What Letters had you late from France?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Be simple answered, for we know the truth.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: And what confederacy have you with the Traitors, late footed in the Kingdom?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: To whose hands
You have sent the Lunatic King: Speak.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I have a Letter guessingly set down
Which came from one that is of a neutral heart,
And not from one opposed.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Cunning.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: And false.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Where hast thou sent the King?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: To Douer.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Wherefore to Douer?
Wast thou not charged at peril.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Wherefore to Douer? Let him answer that.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I am tied to the stake,
And I must stand the Course.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Wherefore to Douer?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Because I would not see thy cruel Nails
Pluck out his poor old eyes: nor thy fierce Sister,
In his Anointed flesh, stick boarish fangs.
The Sea, with such a storm as his bare head,
In Hell-black-night endured, would have buoyed up
And quenched the Stelled fires:
Yet poor old heart, he holp the Heavens to rain.
If Wolves had at thy Gate howled that stern time,
Thou shouldest have said, good Porter turn the Key:
All Cruels else subscribe: but I shall see
The winged Vengeance overtake such Children.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: See it shalt thou never. Fellows hold ye Chair,
Upon these eyes of thine, I will set my foot.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He that will think to live, till he be old,
Give me some help. ---- O cruel! O you Gods.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: One side will mock another: The other too.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: If you see vengeance.

sp.speaker: Ser 1.
sp.l: Hold your hand, my Lord:
I have served you ever since I was a Child:
But better service have I never done you,
Than now to bid you hold.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: How now, you dog?

sp.speaker: Ser 1.
sp.l: If you did wear a beard upon your chin,
I would shake it on this quarrel. What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: My Villain?

sp.speaker: Ser 1.
sp.l: Nay then come on, and take the chance of anger.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Give me thy Sword. A peasant stand up thus?

sp.speaker: Ser 1.
sp.l: O, I am slain: my Lord,you have one eye left
To see some mischief on him. O,.

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: Lest it see more, prevent it; Out vile jelly:
Where is thy luster now?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: All dark and comfortless?
Where is my Son Edmund?
Edmund, enkindle all the sparks of Nature
To quit this horrid act.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Out treacherous Villain,
Thou call'st on him, that hates thee. It was he
That made the overture of thy Treasons to us:
Who is too good to pity thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O my Follies! then Edgar was abused,
Kind Gods, forgive me that,and prosper him.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Go thrust him out at gates, and let him smell
His way to Douer.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: How is it my Lord? How look you?

sp.speaker: Corn.
sp.l: I have received a hurt: Follow me Lady;
Turn out that eyeless Villain: throw this Slave
Upon the Dunghill: Regan, I bleed apace,
Untimely comes this hurt. Give me your arm.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Yet better thus and known to be contemned,
Than still contemned and flattered, to be worst:
The lowest, and most dejected thing of Fortune,
Stands still in esperance, lives not in fear:
The lamentable change is from the best,
The worst returns to laughter. Welcome then,
Thou unsubstantial air that I embrace:
The Wretch that thou hast blown unto the worst,
Owes nothing to thy blasts.

stage.l: Enter Glouster, and an Old man.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: But who comes here? My Father poorly led?
World, World, O world!
But that thy strange mutations make us hate thee,
Life would not yield to age.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: O my good Lord, I have been your Tenant,
And your Father's Tenant, these fourscore years.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Away, get thee away: good Friend be gone,
Thy comforts can do me no good at all,
Thee, they may hurt.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: You cannot see your way.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I have no way, and therefore want no eyes:
I stumbled when I saw. Full oft it is seen,
Our means secure us, and our mere defects
Prove our Commodities. O, dear Son Edgar,
The food of thy abused Father's wrath:
Might I but live to see thee in my touch,
I would say I had eyes again.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: How now? who is there?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O Gods! Who is it can say I am at the worst?
I am worse than ever, I was.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: It is poor mad Tom.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: And worse I may be yet: the worst is not,
So long as we can say this is the worst.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Fellow, where goest?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Is it a Beggar-man?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Madman, and beggar too.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He has some reason, else he could not beg.
In the last night's storm, I such a fellow saw;
Which made me think a Man, a Worm. My Son
Came then into my mind, and yet my mind
Was then scarce Friends with him.
I have heard more since:
As Flies to wanton Boys, are we to the Gods,
They kill us for their sport.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: How should this be?
Bad is the Trade that must play Fool to sorrow,
Angering itself, and others. Bless thee Master.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Is that the naked Fellow?

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Aye, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Get thee away: If for my sake
Thou wilt ore-take us hence a mile or twain
In the way toward Douer, do it for ancient love,
And bring some covering for this naked Soul,
Which I will entreat to lead me.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: Alack sir, he is mad.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is the times plague,
When Madmen lead the blind:
Do as I bid thee, or rather do thy pleasure:
Above the rest, be gone.

sp.speaker: Old Man.
sp.l: I will bring him the best Apparel that I have
Come of it, what will.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sirrah, naked fellow.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Poor Tom is a-cold. I cannot daub it further.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Come hither fellow.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: And yet I must:
Bless thy sweet eyes, they bleed.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Knowest thou the way to Douer?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Both style, and gate; Horseway, and foot-path:
poor Tom hath been scarred out of his good wits. Bless
thee good man's son, from the foul Fiend.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Here take this purse, you whom the heavens' plagues
Have humbled to all strokes: that I am wretched
Makes thee the happier: Heavens deal so still:
Let the superfluous, and Lust-dieted man,
That slaves your ordinance, that will not see
Because he does not feel, feel your power quickly:
So distribution should undo excess,
And each man have enough. Dost thou know Douer?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Aye Master.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: There is a Cliff, whose high and bending head
Looks fearfully in the confined Deep:
Bring me but to the very brim of it,
And I will repair the misery thou dost bear
With something rich about me: from that place,
I shall no leading need.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Give me thy arm;
Poor Tom shall lead thee.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord. I marvel our mild husband
Not met us on the way. Now, where is your Master?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Madam within, but never man so changed:
I told him of the Army that was Landed:
He smiled at it. I told him you were coming,
His answer was, the worse. Of Glosters Treachery,
And of the loyal Service of his Son
When I informed him, then he called me Sot,
And told me I had turned the wrong side out:
What most he should dislike, seems pleasant to him;
What like, offensive.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Then shall you go no further.
It is the Cowish terror of his spirit
That dares not undertake: He will not feel wrongs
Which tie him to an answer: our wishes on the way
May prove effects. Back Edmond to my Brother,
Hasten his Musters, and conduct his powers.
I must change names at home, and give the Distaff
Into my Husband's hands. This trusty Servant
Shall pass between us: ere long you are like to hear
(If you dare venture in your own behalf)
A Mistress's command. Wear this; spare speech,
Decline your head. This kiss, if it durst speak
Would stretch thy Spirits up into the air:
Conceive, and fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Yours in the ranks of death.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: My most dear Gloster.
O, the difference of man, and man,
To thee a Woman's services are due,
My Fool usurps my body.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Madam, here comes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: I have been worth the whistle.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O, Gonerill,
You are not worth the dust which the rude wind
Blows in your face.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Milk-Livered man,
That bearest a cheek for blows, a head for wrongs,
Who hast not in thy brows an eye discerning
Thine Honour, from thy suffering.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: See thyself devil:
Proper deformity seems not in the Fiend
So horrid as in woman.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: O, vain Fool.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: O, my good Lord, the Duke of Cornwall is dead,
Slain by his Servant, going to put out
The other eye of Glouster.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Glousters eyes.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: A Servant that he bred, thrilled with remorse,
Opposed against the act: bending his Sword
To his great Master, who, threat-enraged
Flew on him, and amongst them felled him dead,
But not without that harmful stroke, which since
Hath plucked him after.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: This shows you are above
You Justices, that these our nether crimes
So speedily can venge. But (O poor Glouster)
Lost he his other eye?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Both, both, my Lord.
This Letter Madam, craves a speedy answer:
It is from your Sister.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: One way I like this well,
But being widow, and my Glouster with her,
May all the building in my fancy pluck
Upon my hateful life. Another way
The News is not so tart. I will read, and answer.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Where was his Son,
When they did take his eyes?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Come with my Lady hither.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: He is not here.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: No my good Lord, I met him back again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Knows he the wickedness?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord: it was he informed against him
And quit the house on purpose, that their punishment
Might have the freer course.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Glouster, I live
To thank thee for the love thou showedest the King,
And to revenge thine eyes. Come hither Friend,
Tell me what more thou knowest.

stage.l: Enter with Drum and Colours, Cordelia, Gentlemen,

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Alack, it is he: why he was met even now
As mad as the vexed Sea, singing aloud,
Crowned with rank Fenitar, and furrow weeds,
With burdocks, Hemlock, Nettles, Cuckoo flowers,
Darnel, and all the idle weeds that grow
In our sustaining Corn. A Century send forth;
Search every Acre in the high-grown field,
And bring him to our eye. What can man's wisdom
In the restoring his bereaved Sense; he that helps him,
Take all my outward worth.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: There is means Madam:
Our foster Nurse of Nature, is repose,
The which he lacks: that to provoke in him
Are many Simples operative, whose power
Will close the eye of Anguish.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: All blessed Secrets,
All you unpublished Virtues of the earth
Spring with my tears; be aidant, and remediate
In the Goodman's desires: seek, seek for him,
Lest his ungoverned rage, dissolve the life
That wants the means to lead it.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: News Madam,
The British Powers are marching hitherward.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: It is known before. Our preparation stands
In expectation of them. O dear Father,
It is thy business that I go about: Therefore great France
My mourning, and important tears hath pitied:
No blown Ambition doth our Arms incite,
But love, dear love, and our aged Father's Rite:
Soon may I hear, and see him.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: But are my Brother's Powers set forth?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Aye Madam,

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Himself in person there?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Madam with much ado:
Your Sister is the better Soldier.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Lord Edmund spake not with your Lord at home?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: No Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: What might import my Sister's Letter to him?

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I know not, Lady.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Faith he is posted hence on serious matter:
It was great ignorance, Glousters eyes being out
To let him live. Where he arrives, he moves
All hearts against us: Edmund, I think is gone
In pity of his misery, to dispatch
His nighted life: Moreover to descry
The strength of the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I must needs after him, Madam, with my Letter.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Our troops set forth tomorrow, stay with us:
The ways are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I may not Madam:
My Lady charged my duty in this business.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why should she write to Edmund?
Might not you transport her purposes by word? Belike,
Some things, I know not what. I will love thee much
Let me unseal the Letter.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Madam, I had rather----

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I know your Lady does not love her Husband,
I am sure of that: and at her late being here,
She gave strange Oeliads, and most speaking looks
To Noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosom.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: I, Madam?

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I speak in understanding: You are: I know it,
Therefore I do advise you take this note:
My Lord is dead: Edmond, and I have talked,
And more convenient is he for my hand
Than for your Ladies: You may gather more:
If you do find him, pray you give him this;
And when your Mistress hears thus much from you,
I pray desire her call her wisdom to her.
So fare you well:
If you do chance to hear of that blind Traitor,
Preferment falls on him, that cuts him off.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Would I could meet Madam, I should show
What party I do follow.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: When shall I come to the top of that same hill?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: You do climb up it now. Look how we labour.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Methinks the ground is even.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Horrible steep.
Hark, do you hear the Sea?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No truly.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Why then your other Senses grow imperfect
By your eyes' anguish.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: So may it be indeed.
Methinks thy voice is altered, and thou speakest
In better phrase, and matter than thou didst.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: You are much deceived: In nothing am I changed
But in my Garments.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Methinks you are better spoken.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Come on Sir,
Here is the place: stand still: how fearful
And dizzy it is, to cast ones eyes so low,
The Crows and Choughs, that wing the midway air
Show scarce so gross as Beetles. Half way down
Hangs one that gathers Samphire: dreadful Trade:
Methinks he seems no bigger than his head.
The Fishermen, that walked upon the beach
Appear like Mice: and yond tall Anchoring Bark,
Diminished to her Cock: her Cock, a Buoy
Almost too small for sight. The murmuring Surge,
That on the unnumbered idle Pebble chafes
Cannot be heard so high. I will look no more,
Lest my brain turn, and the deficient sight
Topple down headlong.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Set me where you stand.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Give me your hand:
You are now within a foot of the extreme Verge:
For all beneath the Moon would I not leap upright.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Let go my hand:
Here Friend is another purse: in it, a Jewel
Well worth a poor man's taking. Fairies, and Gods
Prosper it with thee. Go thou further off,
Bid me farewell, and let me hear thee going.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Now fare ye well, good Sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Why I do trifle thus with his despair,
Is done to cure it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O you mighty Gods!
This world I do renounce, and in your sights
Shake patiently my great affliction off:
If I could bear it longer, and not fall
To quarrel with your great opposeless wills,
My snuff, and loathed part of Nature should
Burn itself out. If Edgar live, O bless him:
Now Fellow, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Gone Sir, farewell:
And yet I know not how conceit may rob
The Treasury of life, when life itself
Yields to the Theft. Had he been where he thought,
By this had thought been past. Alive, or dead?
Ho, you Sir: Friend, hear you Sir, speak:
Thus might he pass indeed: yet he revives.
What are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Away, and let me dye.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Hadst thou been aught
But Gossamer, Feathers, Air,
(So many fathom down precipitating)
Thou hadst shivered like an Egg: but thou dost breath:
Hast heavy substance, bleedest not, speakest, art sound,
Ten Masts at each, make not the altitude
Which thou hast perpendicularly fell,
Thy life is a Miracle. Speak yet again.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But have I fallen, or no?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: From the dread Summit of this Chalky Bourn
Look up a height, the shrill-gorged Lark so far
Cannot be seen, or heard: Do but look up.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alack, I have no eyes:
Is wretchedness deprived that benefit
To end itself by death? It was yet some comfort,
When misery could beguile the Tyrant's rage,
And frustrate his proud will.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Give me your arm.
Up, so: How is it? Feel you your Legs? You stand.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Too well, too well.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: This is above all strangeness,
Upon the crown of the Cliff. What thing was that
Which parted from you?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A poor unfortunate Beggar.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: As I stood here below, me thought his eyes
Were two full Moons: he had a thousand Noses,
Horns whelked, and waved like the enraged Sea:
It was some Fiend: Therefore thou happy Father,
Think that the clearest Gods, who make them Honours
Of men's Impossibilities, have preserved thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I do remember now: henceforth I will bear
Affliction, till it do cry out itself
Enough, enough, and dye. That thing you speak of,
I took it for a man: often it would say
The Fiend, the Fiend, he led me to that place.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Bear free and patient thoughts.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: But who comes here?
The safer sense will never accommodate
His Master thus.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
No, they cannot touch me for crying. I am the
King himself.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O thou side-piercing sight!

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Nature is above Art, in that respect. There is your
Press-money. That fellow handles his bow, like a Crowkeeper: draw me a Clothier's yard. Look, look, a
Mouse: peace, peace, this piece of toasted Cheese will
do it. There is my Gauntlet, I will prove it on a Giant.
Bring up the brown Bills. O well flown Bird: in the
clout, in the clout: Hewgh. Give the word.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Sweet Marjorum.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Pass.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I know that voice.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Ha! Gonerill with a white beard? They flattered
me like a Dog, and told me I had the white hairs in
my Beard, ere the black ones were there. To say aye, and
no, to everything that I said: Aye, and no too, was no good
Divinity. When the rain came to wet me once, and the
wind to make me chatter: when the Thunder would not
peace at my bidding, there I found them, there I smelt them
out. Go to, they are not men of their words; they told
me, I was everything: It is a Lie, I am not Ague-proof.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The trick of that voice, I do well remember:
Is it not the King?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Aye, every inch a King.
When I do stare, see how the Subject quakes.
I pardon that man's life. What was thy cause?
Adultery? thou shalt not dye: dye for Adultery?
No, the Wren goes to it, and the small gilded Fly
Does lecher in my sight. Let Copulation thrive:
For Glousters bastard Son was kinder to his Father,
Than my Daughters got tween the lawful sheets.
To it Luxury pell-mell, for I lack Soldiers.
Behold yond simpering Dame, whose face between her
Forks presages Snow; that minces Vertue, and does shake
the head to hear of pleasure's name. The Fitchew, nor
the soiled Horse goes to it with a more riotous appetite: Down from the waste they are Centaurs, though
Women all above: but to the Girdle do the Gods inherit,
beneath is all the Fiend's. There is hell, there is darkness, there is the sulphurous pit; burning, scalding, stench,
consumption: Fie, fie, fie; pah, pah: Give me an Ounce
of Civet; good Apothecary sweeten my imagination:
There is money for thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O let me kiss that hand.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Let me wipe it first,
It smells of Mortality.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O ruined piece of Nature, this great world
Shall so wear out to naught.
Dost thou know me?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
I remember thine eyes well enough: dost thou
squiny at me? No, do thy worst blind Cupid, I will not
love. Read thou this challenge, mark but the penning
of it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Were all thy Letters Suns, I could not see.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I would not take this from report,
It is, and my heart breaks at it.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p: Read.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What with the Case of eyes?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
O, ho, are you there with me? No eyes in your
head, nor no money in your purse? Your eyes are in a heavy case, your purse in a light, yet you see how this world
goes.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I see it feelingly.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
What, art mad? A man may see how this world
goes, with no eyes. Look with thine ears: See how
yond Justice rails upon yond simple thief. Hark in
thine ear: Change places, and handy-dandy, which is
the Justice, which is the thief: Thou hast seen a Farmer's dog bark at a Beggar?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
And the Creature run from the Cur: there thou
mightst behold the great image of Authority, a Dog is
obeyed in Office. Thou, Rascal Beadle, hold thy bloody
hand: why dost thou lash that Whore? Strip thy own
back, thou hotly lusts to use her in that kind, for which
thou whipst her. The Usurer hangs the Cozener. Thorough tattered clothes great Vices do appear: Robes,
and Furred gowns hide all. Place sins with Gold, and
the strong Lance of Justice, hurtless breaks: Arm it in
rags, a Pygmy's straw does pierce it. None does offend,
none, I say none, I will able them; take that of me my Friend,
who have the power to seal the accusers lips. Get thee
glass-eyes, and like a scurvy Politician, seem to see the
things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now. Pull off my
Boots: harder, harder, so.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: O matter, and impertinency mixed,
Reason in Madness.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: If thou wilt weep my Fortunes, take my eyes.
I know thee well enough, thy name is Glouster:
Thou must be patient; we came crying hither:
Thou knowest, the first time that we smell the Air
We waul, and cry. I will preach to thee: Mark.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alack, alack the day.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: When we are borne, we cry that we are come
To this great stage of Fools. This a good blocke:
It were a delicate stratagem to shoo
A Troop of Horse with Felt: I will put it in proof,
And when I have stolen upon these Son-in-laws,
Then kill, kill, kill, kill, kill, kill.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: O, here he is: lay hand upon him, Sir.
Your most dear Daughter----

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No rescue? What, a Prisoner? I am even
The Natural Fool of Fortune. Use me well,
You shall have ransom. Let me have Surgeons,
I am cut to the Brains.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You shall have anything,.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No Seconds? All myself?
Why, this would make a man, a man of Salt
To use his eyes for Garden water-pots. I will die bravely,
Like a smug Bridegroom. What? I will be Jovial:
Come, come, I am a King, Masters, know you that?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: You are a Royal one, and we obey you.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.p:
Then there is life in it. Come, and you get it,
You shall get it by running: Sa, sa, sa, sa.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A sight most pitiful in the meanest wretch,
Past speaking of in a King. Thou hast a Daughter
Who redeems Nature from the general curse
Which twain have brought her to.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Hail gentle Sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Sir, speed you: what is your will?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Do you hear aught (Sir) of a Battle toward.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Most sure, and vulgar:
Everyone hears that, which can distinguish sound.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: But by your favour:
How near is the other Army?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Near, and on speedy foot: the maine descry
Stands on the hourly thought.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, that is all.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Though that the Queen on special cause is here
Her Army is moved on.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: You ever gentle Gods, take my breath from me,
Let not my worser Spirit tempt me again
To dye before you please.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Well pray you Father.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now good sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: A most poor man, made tame to Fortunes blows
Who, by the Art of known, and feeling sorrows,
Am pregnant to good pity. Give me your hand,
I will lead you to some biding.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Hearty thanks:
The bounty, and the benison of Heaven
To boot, and boot.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: A proclaimed prize: most happy
That eyeless head of thine, was first framed flesh
To raise my fortunes. Thou old, unhappy Traitor,
Briefly thyself remember: the Sword is out
That must destroy thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now let thy friendly hand
Put strength enough to it.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Wherefore, bold Peasant,
Darest thou support a published Traitor? Hence,
Lest that the infection of his fortune take
Like hold on thee. Let go his arm.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
I will not let go Sir,
Without further occasion.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Let go Slave, or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
Good Gentleman go your gate, and let poor
folk pass: and I could have been swaggered out of my life,
it would not have been so long as it is, by a fortnight. Nay,
come not near the old man: keep out che vor'ye, or I shall
try whether your Costard, or my Ballow be the harder;
I will be plain with you.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Out Dunghill.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
I will pick your teeth Sir: come, no matter for
your foins.

sp.speaker: Osw.
sp.l: Slave thou hast slain me: Villain, take my purse;
If ever thou wilt thrive, bury my body,
And give the Letters which thou findest about me,
To Edmund Earl of Glouster: seek him out
Upon the English party. O, untimely death, death.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I know thee well. A serviceable Villain,
As duteous to the vices of thy Mistress,
As badness would desire.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Sit you down Father: rest you.
Let us see these Pockets; the Letters that he speaks of
May be my Friends: he is dead; I am only sorry
He had no other Deathsman. Let us see:
Leave gentle wax, and manners: blame us not
To know our enemies' minds, we rip their hearts,
Their Papers is more lawful.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.p:
LEt our reciprocal vows be remembered. You have many
opportunities to cut him off: if your will want not, time and
place will be fruitfully offered. There is nothing done. If he
return the Conqueror,then am I the Prisoner, and his bed, my
Gaol, from the loathed warmth whereof, deliver me, and supply the place for your Labour.
sp.l: Your (Wife, so I would say) affectionate Servant. Gonerill.
O, indistinguished space of Woman's will,
A plot upon her virtuous Husband's life,
And the exchange my Brother: here, in the sands
Thee I will rake up, the post unsanctified
Of murtherous Lechers: and in the mature time,
With this ungracious paper strike the sight
Of the death-practised Duke: for him it is well,
That of thy death, and business, I can tell.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The King is mad:
How stiff is my vile sense
That I stand up, and have ingenious feeling
Of my huge Sorrows? Better I were distract,
So should my thoughts be severed from my griefs,
And woes, by wrong imaginations lose
The knowledge of themselves.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Give me your hand:
Far off methinks I hear the beaten Drum.
Come Father, I will bestow you with a Friend.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O thou good Kent,
How shall I live and work
To match thy goodness?
My life will be too short,
And every measure fail me.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: To be acknowledged Madam is overpaid,
All my reports go with the modest truth,
Nor more, nor clipped, but so.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Be better suited,
These weeds are memories of those worser hours:
I prithee put them off.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Pardon dear Madam,
Yet to be known shortens my made intent,
My boon I make it, that you know me not,
Till time and I, think meet.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Then be it so my good Lord:
How does the King?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Madam sleeps still.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O you kind Gods!
Cure this great breach in his abused Nature,
The untuned and jarring senses, O wind up,
Of this child-changed Father.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: So please your Majesty,
That we may wake the King, he hath slept long?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Be governed by your knowledge, and proceed
In the sway of your own will: is he arrayed?

stage.l: Enter Lear in a chaire carried by Seruants

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Aye Madam: in the heaviness of sleep,
We put fresh garments on him.
Be by good Madam when we do awake him,
I doubt of his Temperance.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O my dear Father, restoration hang
Thy medicine on my lips, and let this kiss
Repair those violent harms, that my two Sisters
Have in thy Reverence made.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Kind and dear Princess.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Had you not been their Father, these white flakes
Did challenge pity of them. Was this a face
To be opposed against the jarring winds?
Mine Enemy's dog, though he had bit me,
Should have stood that night against my fire,
And wast thou fain (poor Father)
To hovel thee with Swine and Rogues forlorn,
In short, and musty straw? Alack, alack,
It is wonder that thy life and wits, at once
Had not concluded all. He wakes, speak to him.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Madam do you, it is fittest.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: How does my Royal Lord?
How fares your Majesty?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You do me wrong to take me out of the grave,
Thou art a Soul in bliss, but I am bound
Upon a wheel of fire, that mine own tears
Do scaled, like molten Lead.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Sir, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You are a spirit I know, where did you dye?

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Still, still, far wide.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: He is scarce awake,
Let him alone a while.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Where have I been?
Where am I? Fair day light?
I am mightily abused; I should even dye with pity
To see another thus. I know not what to say:
I will not swear these are my hands: let us see,
I feel this pin prick, would I were assured
Of my condition.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: O look upon me Sir,
And hold your hand in benediction over me,
You must not kneel.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Pray do not mock me:
I am a very foolish fond old man,
Fourscore and upward,
Not an hour more, nor less:
And to deal plainly,
I fear I am not in my perfect mind.
Methinks I should know you, and know this man,
Yet I am doubtful: For I am mainly ignorant
What place this is: and all the skill I have
Remembers not these garments: nor I know not
Where I did lodge last night. Do not laugh at me,
For (as I am a man) I think this Lady
To be my child Cordelia.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: And so I am: I am.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Be your tears wet?
Yes faith: I pray weep not,
If you have poison for me, I will drink it:
I know you do not love me, for your Sisters
Have (as I do remember) done me wrong.
You have some cause, they have not.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: No cause, no cause.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Am I in France?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: In your own kingdom Sir.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Do not abuse me.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.l: Be comforted good Madam, the great rage
You see is killed in him: desire him to go in,
Trouble him no more till further settling.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: Will it please your Highness walk?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You must bear with me:
Pray you now forget, and forgive,
I am old and foolish.

stage.l: Enter with Drumme and Colours, Edmund, Regan.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold,
Or whether since he is advised by aught
To change the course, he is full of alteration,
And self-reproving, bring his constant pleasure.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Our Sister's man is certainly miscarried.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: It is to be doubted Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Now sweet Lord,
You know the goodness I intend upon you:
Tell me but truly, but then speak the truth,
Do you not love my Sister?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: In honoured Love.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: But have you never found my Brother's way,
To the fore-fended place?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: No by mine honour, Madam.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: I never shall endure her, dear my Lord
Be not familiar with her.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Fear not, she and the Duke her husband.

stage.l: Enter with Drum and Colours, Albany, Gonerill, Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Our very loving Sister, well be-met:
Sir, this I heard, the King is come to his Daughter
With others, whom the rigour of our State
Forced to cry out.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Why is this reasoned?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Combine together against the Enemy:
For these domestic and particular broils,
Are not the question here.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Let us then determine with the ancient of war
On our proceeding.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sister you will go with us?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: It is most convenient, pray go with us.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: O, ho, I know the Riddle, I will go.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: If ever, your Grace had speech with man so poor,
Hear me one word.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I will overtake you, speak.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Before you fight the Battle, ope this Letter:
If you have victory, let the Trumpet sound
For him that brought it: wretched though I seem,
I can produce a Champion, that will prove
What is avouched there. If you miscarry,
Your business of the world hath so an end,
And machination ceases. Fortune loves you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stay till I have read the Letter.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: I was forbid it:
When time shall serve, let but the Herald cry,
And I will appear again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why fare thee well, I will overlook thy paper.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: The Enemy is in view, draw up your powers,
Here is the guess of their true strength and Forces,
By diligent discovery, but your hast
Is now urged on you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: We will greet the time.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: To both these Sisters have I sworn my love:
Each jealous of the other, as the stung
Are of the Adder. Which of them shall I take?
Both? One ? Or neither? Neither can be enjoyed
If both remain alive: To take the Widow,
Exasperates, makes mad her Sister Gonerill,
And hardly shall I carry out my side,
Her husband being alive. Now then, we will use
His countenance for the Battle, which being done,
Let her who would be rid of him, devise
His speedy taking off. As for the mercy
Which he intends to Lear and to Cordelia,
The Battle done, and they within our power,
Shall never see his pardon: for my state,
Stands on me to defend, not to debate.

stage.l: Alarum within. Enter with Drumme and Colours, Lear,
Cordelia, and Souldiers, ouer the Stage, and Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Here Father, take the shadow of this Tree
For your good host: pray that the right may thrive:
If ever I return to you again,
I will bring you comfort.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Grace go with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Away old man, give me thy hand, away:
King Lear hath lost, he and his Daughter taken,
Give me thy hand: Come on.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No further Sir, a man may rot even here.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: What in ill thoughts again?
Men must endure
Their going hence, even as their coming hither,
Ripeness is all come on.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: And that is true too.

div2.head: Scena Tertia.

stage.l: Enter in conquest with Drum and Colours, Edmund, Lear,
and Cordelia, as prisoners, Souldiers, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Some Officers take them away: good guard,
Until their greater pleasures first be known
That are to censure them.

sp.speaker: Cord.
sp.l: We are not the first,
Who with best meaning have incurred the worst:
For thee oppressed King I am cast down,
Myself could else out-frown false Fortunes frown.
Shall we not see these Daughters, and these Sisters?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No, no, no, no: come let us away to prison,
We two alone will sing like Birds in the Cage:
When thou dost ask me blessing, I will kneel down
And ask of thee forgiveness: So we will live,
And pray, and sing, and tell old tales, and laugh
At gilded Butterflies: and hear (poor Rogues)
Talk of Court news, and we will talk with them too,
Who looses, and who wins; who is in, who is out;
And take upon us the mystery of things,
As if we were God's spies: And we will wear out
In a walled prison, packs and sects of great ones,
That ebb and flow by the Moon.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Take them away.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Upon such sacrifices my Cordelia,
The Gods themselves throw Incense.
Have I caught thee?
He that parts us, shall bring a Brand from Heaven,
And fire us hence, like Foxes: wipe thine eyes,
The good years shall devour them, flesh and fell,
Ere they shall make us weep?
We will see them starved first: come.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Come hither Captain, hark.
Take thou this note, go follow them to prison,
One step I have advanced thee, if thou dost
As this instructs thee, thou dost make thy way
To Noble Fortunes: know thou this, that men
Are as the time is; to be tender minded
Does not become a Sword, thy great employment
Will not bear question: either say thou wilt do it,
Or thrive by other means.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.l: I will do it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: About it, and write happy, when thou hast done,
Mark I say instantly, and carry it so
As I have set it down.

stage.l: Flourish. Enter Albany, Gonerill, Regan, Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir, you have showed today your valiant strain
And Fortune led you well: you have the Captives
Who were the opposites of this day's strife:
I do require them of you so to use them,
As we shall find their merits, and our safety
May equally determine.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Sir, I thought it fit,
To send the old and miserable King to some retention,
Whose age had Charms in it, whose Title more,
To pluck the common bosom on his side,
And turn our impressed Lances in our eyes
Which do command them. With him I sent the Queen:
My reason all the same, and they are ready
Tomorrow, or at further space, to appear
Where you shall hold your Session.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir, by your patience,
I hold you but a subject of this War,
Not as a Brother.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: That is as we list to grace him.
Methinks our pleasure might have been demanded
Ere you had spoke so far. He led our Powers,
Bore the Commission of my place and person,
The which immediacy may well stand up,
And call itself your Brother.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Not so hot:
In his own grace he doth exalt himself,
More than in your addition.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: In my rights,
By me invested, he compeers the best.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: That were the most, if he should husband you.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Jesters do oft prove Prophets.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Hola, hola,
That eye that told you so, looked but a-squint.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Lady I am not well, else I should answer
From a full flowing stomach. General,
Take thou my Soldiers, prisoners, patrimony,
Dispose of them, of me, the walls is thine:
Witness the world, that I create thee here
My Lord, and Master.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Mean you to enjoy him?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The let alone lies not in your good will.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Nor in thine Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Half-blooded fellow, yes.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Let the Drum strike, and prove my title thine.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stay yet, hear reason: Edmund, I arrest thee
On capital Treason; and in thy arrest,
This gilded Serpent: for your claim fair Sisters,
I bare it in the interest of my wife,
It is she is sub-contracted to this Lord,
And I her husband contradict your Banes.
If you will marry, make your loves to me,
My Lady is bespoke.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: An interlude.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Thou art armed Gloster,
Let the Trumpet sound:
If none appear to prove upon thy person,
Thy heinous, manifest, and many Treasons,
There is my pledge: I will make it on thy heart
Ere I taste bread, thou art in nothing less
Than I have here proclaimed thee.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: Sick, O sick.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: If not, I will never trust medicine.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: There is my exchange, what in the world he is
That names me Traitor, villain-like he lies,
Call by the Trumpet: he that dares approach;
On him, on you, who not, I will maintain
My truth and honour firmly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: A Herald, ho.
Trust to thy single vertue, for thy Soldiers
All levied in my name, have in my name
Took their discharge.

sp.speaker: Reg.
sp.l: My sickness grows upon me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: She is not well, convey her to my Tent.
Come hither Herald, let the Trumpet sound,
And read out this.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p:
If any man of quality or degree, within the lists of the Army, will maintain upon Edmund, supposed Earl of Gloster,
that he is a manifold Traitor, let him appear by the third
sound of the Trumpet: he is bold in his defence.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Again.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: Again.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ask him his purposes, why he appears
Upon this Call of the Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: What are you?
Your name, your quality, and why you answer
This present Summons?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Know my name is lost
By Treason's tooth: bare-gnawn, and Canker-bit,
Yet am I Noble as the Adversary
I come to cope.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Which is that Adversary?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: What is he that speaks for Edmund Earl of Gloster?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Himself, what sayst thou to him?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Draw thy Sword,
That if my speech offend a Noble heart,
Thy arm may do thee Justice, here is mine:
Behold it is my privilege,
The privilege of mine Honours,
My oath, and my profession. I protest,
Maugre thy strength, place, youth, and eminence,
Despise thy victor-Sword, and fire new Fortune,
Thy valour, and thy heart, thou art a Traitor:
False to thy Gods, thy Brother, and thy Father,
Conspirant against this high illustrious Prince,
And from the extremest upward of thy head,
To the descent and dust below thy foot,
A most Toad-spotted Traitor. Say thou no,
This Sword, this arm, and my best spirits are bent
To prove upon thy heart, whereto I speak,
Thou liest.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: In wisdom I should ask thy name,
But since thy out-side looks so fair and Warlike,
And that thy tongue (some say) of breeding breathes,
What safe, and nicely I might well delay,
By rule of Knight-hood, I disdain and spurn:
Back do I toss these Treasons to thy head,
With the hell-hated Lie, overwhelm thy heart,
Which for they yet glance by, and scarcely bruise,
This Sword of mine shall give them instant way,
Where they shall rest forever. Trumpets speak.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Save him, save him.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: This is practice Gloster,
By the law of War, thou wast not bound to answer
An unknown opposite: thou art not vanquished,
But cozened, and beguiled.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Shut your mouth Dame,
Or with this paper shall I stop it: hold Sir,
Thou worse than any name, read thine own evil:
No tearing Lady, I perceive you know it.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Say if I do, the Laws are mine not thine,
Who can arraign me for it?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Most monstrous! O, knowest thou this paper?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Ask me not what I know.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Go after her, she is desperate, govern her.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: What you have charged me with,
That have I done,
And more, much more, the time will bring it out.
It is past, and so am I: But what art thou
That hast this Fortune on me? If thou art Noble,
I do forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Let us exchange charity:
I am no less in blood than thou art Edmond,
If more, the more thou hast wronged me.
My name is Edgar and thy Father's Son,
The Gods are just, and of our pleasant vices
Make instruments to plague us:
The dark and vicious place where thee he got,
Cost him his eyes.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Thou hast spoken right, it is true,
The Wheel is come full circle, I am here.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Methought thy very gate did prophesy
A Royal Nobleness: I must embrace thee,
Let sorrow split my heart, if ever I
Did hate thee, or thy father.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Worthy Prince I know it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Where have you hid yourself?
How have you known the miseries of your Father?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: By nursing them my Lord. List a brief tale,
And when it is told, O that my heart would burst.
The bloody proclamation to escape
That followed me so near, (O our lives' sweetness,
That we the pain of death would hourly dye,
Rather than die at once) taught me to shift
Into a madman's rags, to assume a semblance
That very Dogs disdained: and in this habit
Met I my Father with his bleeding Rings,
Their precious Stones new lost: became his guide,
Led him, begged for him, saved him from despair.
Never (O fault) revealed myself unto him,
Until some half hour past when I was armed,
Not sure, though hoping of this good success,
I asked his blessing, and from first to last
Told him our pilgrimage. But his flawed heart
(Alack too weak the conflict to support)
Twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief,
Burst smilingly.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: This speech of yours hath moved me,
And shall perchance do good, but speak you on,
You look as you had something more to say.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: If there be more, more woeful, hold it in,
For I am almost ready to dissolve,
Hearing of this.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Help, help: O help.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: What kind of help?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Speak man.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: What means this bloody Knife?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It is hot, it smokes, it came even from the heart
of----O she is dead.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Who dead? Speak man.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Your Lady Sir, your Lady; and her Sister
By her is poisoned: she confesses it.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: I was contracted to them both, all three
Now marry in an instant.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Here comes Kent.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Produce the bodies, be they alive or dead;

div2.stage: Gonerill and Regans bodies brought out.

sp.l: This judgment of the Heavens that makes us tremble.
Touches us not with pity: O, is this he?
The time will not allow the complement
Which very manners urges.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I am come
To bid my King and Master aye good night.
Is he not here?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Great thing of us forgot,
Speak Edmund, where is the King? and where is Cordelia?
Seest thou this object Kent?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Alack, why thus?

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Yet Edmund was beloved:
The one the other poisoned for my sake,
And after slew herself.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Even so: cover their faces.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: I pant for life: some good I mean to do
Despite of mine own Nature. Quickly send,
(Be brief in it) to the Castle, for my Writ
Is on the life of Lear, and on Cordelia:
Nay, send in time.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Run, run, O run.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: To who my Lord? Who ha is the Office?
Send thy token of reprieve.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: Well thought on, take my Sword,
Give it the Captain.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Haste thee for thy life.

sp.speaker: Edm.
sp.l: He hath Commission from thy Wife and me,
To hang Cordelia in the prison, and
To lay the blame upon her own despair,
That she for-did herself.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The Gods defend her, bear him hence awhile.

stage.l: Enter Lear with Cordelia in his armes.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Howl, howl, howl: O your are men of stones,
Had I your tongues and eyes, I would use them so,
That Heaven's vault should crack: she is gone forever.
I know when one is dead, and when one lives,
She is dead as earth: Lend me a Looking-glass,
If that her breath will mist or stain the stone,
Why then she lives.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Is this the promised end?

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Or image of that horror.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Fall and cease.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: This feather stirs , she lives: if it be so,
It is a chance which does redeem all sorrows
That ever I have felt.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: O my good Master.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Prithee away.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: It is Noble Kent your Friend.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: A plague upon you Murderers, Traitors all,
I might have saved her, now she is gone forever:
Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little. Ha:
What is it thou sayst? Her voice was ever soft,
Gentle, and low, an excellent thing in woman.
I killed the Slave that was a-hanging thee.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It is true (my Lords) he did.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Did I not fellow?
I have seen the day, with my good biting Falchion
I would have made him skip: I am old now,
And these same crosses spoil me. Who are you?
Mine eyes are not of the best, I will tell you straight.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: If Fortune brag of two, she loved and hated,
One of them we behold.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: This is a dull sight, are you not Kent?

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: The same: your Servant Kent,
Where is your Servant Caius?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: He is a good fellow, I can tell you that,
He will strike and quickly too, he is dead and rotten.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: No my good Lord, I am the very man.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I will see that straight.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: That from your first of difference and decay,
Have followed your sad steps.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You are welcome hither.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Nor no man else:
All is cheerless, dark, and deadly,
Your eldest Daughters have fore-done themselves,
And desperately are dead

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Aye so I think.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: He knows not what he says, and vain is it
That we present us to him.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Very bootless.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: Edmund is dead my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: That is but a trifle here:
You Lords and Noble Friends, know our intent,
What comfort to this great decay may come,
Shall be applied. For us we will resign,
During the life of this old Majesty
To him our absolute power, you to your rights,
With boot, and such addition as your Honours
Have more than merited. All Friends shall
Taste the wages of their vertue, and all Foes
The cup of their deservings: O see, see.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: And my poor Fool is hanged: no, no, no life?
Why should a Dog, a Horse, a Rat have life,
And thou no breath at all? Thou wilt come no more,
Never, never, never, never, never.
Pray you undo this Button. Thank you Sir,
Do you see this? Look on her? Look her lips,
Look there, look there.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: He faints, my Lord, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Break heart, I prithee break.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: Look up my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: Vex not his ghost, O let him pass, he hates him,
That would upon the wrack of this tough world
Stretch him out longer.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: He is gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: The wonder is, he hath endured so long,
He but usurped his life.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Bear them from hence, our present business
Is general woe : Friends of my soul, you twain,
Rule in this Realm, and the gored state sustain.

sp.speaker: Kent.
sp.l: I have a journey Sir, shortly to go,
My Master calls me, I must not say no.

sp.speaker: Edg.
sp.l: The weight of this sad time we must obey,
Speak what we feel, not what we aught to say:
The oldest hath borne most, we that are young,
Shall never see so much, nor live so long.
